No bottle of hair dye could possibly hold as much history as Clairol nice ’n easy, No 512, a shade of dark auburn launched in 1975. The extraordinary face on the side of its bottle belonged to Tracey Norman, one of the first African American models to make it big and the second black woman, after Beverly Johnson, to appear on the cover of Vogue.

By the time her large eyes and sharp cheekbones became the face of No 512, Norman’s career was booming and her shade became a bestseller soon after its launch. Laverne Cox, best known for her role in the TV series Orange is the New Black, remembers Norman’s face on that bottle, as do many other millions of American women. As Cox told New York Magazine last year: “I can’t tell you how many hours I stared at that photo of her on that Clairol bottle and that caption, ‘Born Beautiful’. Yeah, we are born beautiful.”

Norman, however, was keeping an extraordinary secret. As a trans woman she was making history, all the while hoping that no one else would ever know. Cox, a trans actor, and every other woman who bought a bottle of No 512, had no idea that the beautiful black woman on the side of the Clairol bottle had begun life as a biological boy. Norman was, in short, the first black transgender model.

In recent years, rapid if overdue progress has been made in the realm of trans rights and trans visibility. Now trans models such as Andreja Pejić, Carmen Carrera, Lea T and Hari Nef walk runways and secure campaigns for major fashion labels. Forty years ago, however, the word “trans” barely existed and prejudice was such that the idea of a trans model being “out” was unthinkable, even horrifying, to a far less enlightened world. As such, Norman would say a prayer before each shoot: “Please don’t let this be the day.”

She “passed” as a cisgender female for years before that day came around in 1980. Norman was, as she understands it, outed on a shoot and with that, her career was in effect terminated. Now, however, Clairol has welcomed her back into the spotlight and in front of the camera. Last week the brand announced Norman, 63, as the face of its new “Color As Real As You Are” campaign. In the accompanying video, Norman reminds us: “Back in the 70s it was a different world for transgender women … I had to hide my truth.” The clip ends: “It’s good to be back and it’s really good to be me.”

Clairol’s global associate brand director Heather Carruthers said: “We’re honoured to bring back Tracey Norman as a woman who no longer has to hide her truth.”

In the words of Janet Mock, a transgender advocate and the author of the bestselling memoir Redefining Realness, Norman’s reunion with Clairol is “one of those full-circle narratives of affirmation and acceptance that further chips away at the persistent myth most trans people have done so much work to unlearn: that we are not enough – not good enough or ‘real’ enough.” Mock also points out that Norman is not just African American and trans, but a woman in her 60s – an age, she says, “when our society tells women to go away and hide”.

Mock adds: “As a black trans woman who has to grapple with a culture that tells me I am not beautiful because I am trans and I am not beautiful because I am black, seeing this living legend shine is a beacon of affirmation that, yes, we are beautiful, but more importantly we are whole, deserving and worthy.”

For Norman, who knew from a very young age that her body did not match her gender, such affirmation was hard to come by. Born in Newark, New Jersey, she was the first person in her family to graduate from high school. On the same day in 1969 that she received her diploma, she summoned the courage to tell her mother the truth. Her mother, in turn, told her she had always known.

Within two years, Norman had begun taking hormones, thanks to a doctor working under the table for the transgender community, and was not just “passing” as female, but turning heads for her beauty. She became interested, albeit tentatively, in the idea of modelling.

One day in 1975 she spotted a group of well-known black models on the street and followed them into the Pierre hotel in New York, assuming they were heading to a fashion show. In fact they were heading to a casting. Norman, who hung back so as to be last in line, found herself facing a panel of three people. She had no idea that they were an Italian Vogue editor, the fashion designer Luciano Soprani and the photographer Irving Penn. To her astonishment, she received a phone call the next day telling her she was booked for a two-day photoshoot that paid $3,000 – more money than Norman had seen in her life. By little more than chance and chutzpah, a black girl from New Jersey in 1970s America had just gone from virtually nothing to the pages of Vogue. Only Norman knew that the whole truth was even more extraordinary.

Related: Laverne Cox: 'Now I have the money to feminise my face I don’t want to. I’m happy'

Enthusiastically endorsed by Penn, who bragged that he had discovered the next Beverly Johnson, Norman signed to Zoli agency, which began, as she has put it, “booking me left and right”.

One of her most loyal clients was Essence, a magazine Norman had worked with plenty of times before it booked her for a shoot for its Christmas issue. All was going well until a hair assistant, a man who had always asked Norman probing questions about her past, entered the shoot and spoke to the magazine’s editor, Susan Taylor. Norman recalled that, soon after, the shoot was shut down and, with it, her career. She believes the hair assistant had discovered her secret. Taylor has since told New York Magazine that she has no recollection of this: “No one could have outed her to me. I always suspected she was genetically male. I accepted her as she presented herself, as an exquisitely beautiful black woman.”

None the less, Norman maintains this is the day her career ended. As she told New York Magazine: “Beauty and fashion is all about illusion. So when the doors were opened for me, I walked right through. And then the doors slammed … Once the doors closed, I was no longer a woman and I no longer got the respect of a woman.”

About 18 months after that shoot, Norman bought a ticket to Paris where she got by for two years working in mostly low-profile jobs. Then, she returned to New York and signed with a small agency. When she was hired for an Ultra Sheen cosmetics ad, her third beauty contract, it seemed like a comeback. And yet word had spread so fast in New York that when the ad ran, everyone knew her foremost as “the girl who’d been a boy”.

After that she was unable to get work and she gave up her apartment and moved back in with her mother. In the intervening years, Norman has earned a living at Show Center, a burlesque peep show featuring trans women in Times Square. She has also become an “icon” and “legend” (these terms have specific status) in the ballroom community, in which different houses, which operate like surrogate families for LGBTQ youth of colour, compete against each other in drag balls. She rose to the rank of “mother” in the House of Africa, hence her full name, Tracey Africa Norman, and in 2001, she was inducted into the ballroom house of fame.

The success of her Vogue days, however, seemed distant and irretrievable. Then, last December, New York Magazine ran a cover story and, once again, her life changed. Norman, who has spent decades training herself in invisibility as a mode of survival, needed convincing to agree to such high-profile press. Yet, “I was reminded,” she said, “that I made history and I deserve to have it printed.”

In the wake of the profile, Norman’s career has been reborn. That is most evident in the Clairol contract – a personal triumph and homecoming for a woman shunned by her profession for decades. More important, though, it is a triumph for trans visibility.

As she told the Huffington Post: “I’m hoping people will take away from this that I am human and I was presented with this great opportunity to better my life. Unfortunately, because of people’s prejudices I was not able to do it.” Unlike so many, however, she was afforded a second chance.

“My friends are very jealous as I will get to watch TV and eat a lot of cake,” says Anastasia Duncanson when asked about her new job.

Ahead of the hotly anticipated seventh series of The Great British Bake Off, which starts on Wednesday, the 30-year-old groceries buyer has just been appointed by Morrisons as the UK’s first dedicated “bake officer”.

Related: The banker, the pastor and the ticking timebomb: meet the 2016 Bake Off contestants

She has been charged with making sure that the retailer’s 492 stores are fully stocked with baking essentials such as flour, icing sugar, yeast, vanilla extract and chocolate chips, and that the stores are also on emergency standby to supply any unexpected or unlikely ingredients that appear on the show – which last year included crystallised ginger and goldenberries, a sweet and tangy superfruit originally from Peru.

Such is the power of the “Bake Off effect” over sales that the UK’s supermarkets and retailers are this year sparing no expense in making sure they are fully geared up to meet demand as the new series kicks off.

Though not all will have created new jobs based on anticipated GBBO sales, all the major UK supermarkets and cookware retailers have bolstered their buying teams. And from behind the scenes they will be closely monitoring the 12 contestants’ artistry on social media (most contestants have their own websites and Instagram accounts) once their creations have been aired on TV.

The programme, now one of the most popular in the UK, has sparked a boom in the art of home baking and a nationwide consumer fascination with soggy bottoms and fancy biscuits.

Related: Bake Off's Mary Berry fed me horse meat, says Sue Perkins

“The Great British Bake Off is now the third most important event in the nation’s home-baking calendar, beaten only by Christmas and Easter,” says Tim Shaw, baking buyer at Waitrose. “While we can predict the increase in sales of regular baking products, the show always throws a curveball, with a contestant using a relatively niche ingredient – such as the goldenberries which appeared in the last series. That ingredient will then fly off the shelves, so I will be glued to each episode again, anticipating what that product will be.”

Last summer, Waitrose reported a 180% sales spike in goldenberries and, after the biscuit episode – which saw all the contestants rustle up 24 biscotti biscuits, puff-pastry arlettes, and an edible biscuit box – sales of ground almonds at Waitrose alone shot up by 161%, flaked almonds by 103% and crystallised ginger by an amazing 315%.

I expect to see metallic frosting, edible glitter and 'cake lace' effects, as well as gravity-defying cakes

Anastasia Duncanson, 'bake officer' at Morrisons

Enthusiastic home baker Duncanson, who is already on Morrisons bakery buying team, cut her teeth on “longlife bread” (such as brioche), and has now been put in charge of monitoring buying trends prompted by the show.

She will ensure it has the most popular ingredients in store, after an “unprecedented spike” last year in sales of glacé cherries and almond extract – up 163% and 110% respectively.

“Some of the trends I expect to see are metallic frosting, edible glitter and “cake lace” effects, as well as gravity-defying cakes, which use special equipment,” she says.

Retail insiders insist that they receive no tip-offs from the BBC in advance, so have to be quick to, er, rise to the challenge of supplying new ingredients, ensuring a fast turnaround.

However, in an interview with the show’s judges, Paul Hollywood and Mary Berry, released today by the team behind the programme, Hollywood lets slip some information that will set supermarket buyers rushing to the phones. “There were some strange tea flavours [in this series], and they were infusing them to bake cakes,” he says.

Berry hints that not all of these creations were successful. “They will use these infusions that you normally find in a drink of tea, but it doesn’t always come through in a cake. You have got to really hunt for it.”

The new series will be the seventh of The Great British Bake Off, which started in 2010, and also led to the most-viewed TV episode of 2015, when Nadiya Hussain captured the nation’s hearts (and a commission to bake a 90th birthday cake for the Queen) when she won the sixth series.

Hussain’s peanut salted caramel and chocolate tart – along with a chocolate bread with salted caramel dipping sauce made by rival Ugne Bubnaityte – led to sales of Waitrose Cooks’ Homebaking Salted Caramel Flavouring increasing by 33% compared with the previous year.

At Marks & Spencer, Elizabeth Morgan, home baking buyer and head of all things Bake Off, says the show has become a British institution, adding that she has to be on the ball ahead of each episode by noting what the upcoming baking challenge will be so that she can attempt to stock up on the likely ingredients in anticipation.

Jenny Watson, creative kitchen buyer at Hobbycraft, says the craft supplies chain is bolstering its supplies of bright colours in its range, from food colour pastes to paint pens, paint brushes, edible glitter, sprinkles and icing.

She say that her “eyes” on the series will be the retailer’s online and social media team, and that she will be working closely with them from the minute this year’s Bake Off starts, on Wednesday evening.

Veronica Davidson, Lakeland’s bakeware buyer, said she has seen the trend for anti-gravity cake kits (used to create cakes whose garnishes appear to float in mid-air) growing since the last series of Bake Off, when winner Nadiya Hussain made a cheesecake that appeared to have a fizzy drink can hovering above it, balanced on a stream of meringue.

“Our original anti-gravity cake kit is now in our top five bakeware best sellers,” she says. “We expect these to become equally, if not even more, popular this autumn as customers endeavour to create their own showstoppers at home.”

As for Duncanson, even when Bake Off is over in October, she will still have her work cut out: “I will be moving straight on to Christmas cakes and then mince pies.”

What we rushed out to buy during last year’s Great British Bake Off

Goldenberries

A sweet and tangy superfruit, these became sought after when finalist (and now Guardian writer) Tamal Ray added them to his biscuit mixture.

Crystallised ginger

This was used extensively, both in the biscuit round and as an ingredient in Nadiya Hussain’s showstopping fizzy pop cheesecake.

Salted caramel

Used both in Hussain’s peanut salted caramel and chocolate tart and rival Ugne Bubnaityte’s chocolate bread with a salted caramel dipping sauce.

Ground almonds and almond flakes

These featured in numerous recipes, including the frangipane tarts contestants were tasked to create in one of the signature challenges.

Per tradition, the men’s marathon will help close out this year’s Olympic Games. On Sunday, hundreds of runners from around the world will make their way through the streets of Rio, starting from and returning to the Sambódromo – a massive, concrete stadium that is home to city’s annual Carnival parades.

What does it take to compete in the grueling 26.2-mile race? Ahead of the Games, the Guardian asked celebrated running coach Bob Larsen, who has worked with American marathon star Meb Keflezighi for more than 20 years.

Keflezighi, an Eritrean refugee who came to the US in 1987, will compete in his fourth Olympic marathon on Sunday. At age 41, he’s the oldest American runner to ever make the Olympic team.

Keflezighi previously won a silver medal at the Athens Olympics in 2004 and came in fourth in London eight years later. He has won dozens of other championships, including the New York and Boston marathons (in 2009 and 2014, respectively).

The Guardian spoke with coach Larsen about how elite runners approach the marathon both physically and mentally – and how more casual runners can run their best race, too.

You can hear Larsen’s advice in the Guardian’s RioRun interactive podcast, which takes listeners on a virtual audio tour of Rio de Janeiro along the Olympic marathon course. But, ahead of Sunday’s race, we’ve excerpted some key passages from the interview below.

The interview has been edited for length and clarity.

The Guardian: Let’s start with this year’s games. What are you and Meb [Keflezighi] looking forward to about Rio? What is Meb hoping to accomplish?

Bob Larsen: No American has ever made the Olympic marathon team at age 40, which Meb did in the trials. He’s now 41. We have to be realistic that he can’t do some of the things in a marathon that he could when he was younger. But his endurance is still quite high and he’ll be ready to handle the heat, which he does quite well.

At his age, he’s had the experience, so the race won’t overwhelm him. And he has a good backup crew – myself and others – that are there for him. We’ll have him ready to do his best. In the race itself, he has to make good decisions, as he normally does, based on the weather, based on the surging that other guys do.

Obviously you’d love to see Meb in position to have another shot at a medal. Whether he can do that again? I would hope so. I know he’s got the willpower, I know he’s as tough as anybody, and we’ll find out on the 21st of August.

What are some of the main challenges facing marathon runners in Rio? You mentioned weather …

The challenge will be the really warm weather and fairly high humidity. It is their winter, but if it follows the normal pattern for weather for Rio that day, traditionally, on August 21 it’ll be in the high 70s Fahrenheit, humidity in the 75-85% range.

That’s warm for a marathon. You have to be a little bit more cautious as to how difficult the pace is going to be, knowing that it’s going to be a warm day. Ideally, you’d want it a little bit under 50F. When it’s cooler, you use less energy, but that won’t be the case, certainly, in Rio.

Otherwise, this marathon in Rio is relatively flat. There’s a little bit of an incline in one area but essentially it’s a pretty level, straightforward run. You do a 10,000m loop three times and then you run back to the start/finish line. [Editor’s note: Check it out on RioRun.]

And Meb’s prepared for the heat?

We’ve been through this many times, including in Athens in 2004, which was extreme heat, and Meb handled it as well or better than anyone else. So that’ll give him some advantages.

What’s the strategy for running a good race at this level of competition?

With elite runners I’ve always recommended that at the beginning of the race they almost feel like they’re just going on an easy, long road run with their buddies on the weekend. Not to psych up but psych down, for hopefully the first 20 miles, so that they’re not using extra energy on what’s going on but just relax.

Now obviously, if a competitor goes out really hard at the beginning or they surge – and more and more we see this in elite races – then you’ve got to respond and figure out whether you’re gonna go with him or stay back. Those decisions are crucial too.

The most important part of the race will be that last 10,000m (6.2miles). So you don’t want to use up too much energy on your way to 20 miles. Once you get to 20, then you have to make even quicker decisions as to what you’re going to do with surging or to cover surges or whether you want to push the pace yourself, especially if you don’t think you have the speed to get in front of people or to beat them at the end of the race. So there’s a lot that goes into this. Tactics are very important.

If you make a major mistake and go too hard too early and overheat the body then you’re pretty much cooked. You’re maybe not going to be able to do much or be there at the end of the race.

What you’re trying to do is put yourself in position with 10,000m to go, if you feel you have a chance at the medal, to give yourself the best opportunity to get one of those three medals.

What’s the difference between how a casual runner would approach a marathon versus an elite runner, like Meb?

A recreational runner is not so concerned with placement so he can be more aware of exactly what would work well for him to run his fastest race.

One of the best ways of doing that is to start out the first five miles a little slower than what you think you can average all the way through the race. Because for your first five miles you tend to get a little excited, and go too fast, and also you’re not as efficient as you are after you get a little bit more warmed up. So those first five miles, it’s very critical that you hold back.

Then in the middle, you’re trying to run a little bit faster than what your average pace overall will be for the duration of the race.

And then last five miles, or the last 10,000m, you’re hopeful that you can run duplicating the first part of the race. And that’s an efficient way to run it when you’re not racing against other people.

With elite athletes you don’t have those choices. Because if you’re going to stay with people, the race could suddenly change at any point and you’ve got to be ready. So there isn’t one set pattern that an athlete is going to have going into the race. He has to make decisions as he runs.

Ideally you go out a little bit slow, like the recreational runner would do, run fast in the middle, and hope for the best the last few miles. Or certainly, in the Olympic games, you’d love to get a medal, and the top athletes are all trying to do that.

What’s the runner’s mental state during such a demanding race? I imagine elite athletes can’t afford to daydream.

An elite runner is constantly monitoring what he’s doing: what the splits are; is he doing the right pace; what other people are doing around him; and concentrating on perfecting the stride and upper body mechanics so he’s as efficient as he possibly can be.

The recreational runner can afford to think about a lot of different things – and that might be an advantage because you’re out there for so long in a marathon that you really don’t have to think about the mechanics. Just stay relaxed, make sure you’re staying within the pace you should be on. Other than that, just enjoy running out there with your friends, and even chatting and stuff like that. I think that’s fine.

But that’s the difference between that casual level of runner and that elite runner: the elite runner is almost like monitoring a race car, where you’re constantly paying attention to what’s going on and you’re very alert and trying to stay on top of things.

What sets Meb apart?

One of Meb’s assets is that he still thinks clearly at the end of a race. Your oxygen is going to your legs and your heart to keep the body moving forward, so people get to a point where they don’t want to think or they’re not making real good decisions many times.

Meb, even late in the race when he’s being pressured, he still makes good decisions. That really separates him from a lot of runners. He can push himself to keep going hard even when there’s a lot of pain and discomfort at that point in the race. And he is monitoring other people and looking for signs that their technique is faltering or they are breathing harder. He’s just looking for weaknesses in other people in that last 10,000m.

When he won the Boston Marathon the year after the bombing, he was out by himself in front … and the two Kenyans are coming at him very fast and they get within five seconds late in the race, in the last couple of miles, and Meb is going in his mind through everything that he has to do right. That his stride mechanics has to be exact, that’s he’s got to be very careful how he’s placing his foot, his knee coming up and coming off of his heel really quickly – those types of things that he works on all the time. He does drills almost every day, so that really paid off for him.

He’s still got to stay relaxed, and he’s reminding himself of all those things. And then the two Kenyans who are closing on him, who had to run really fast for the previous 10,000m to catch him, now they’re getting a little bit sloppy, their bodies are twisting, they’re not using their arms as efficiently, their knees are no longer coming up as well.

And in some ways that was the difference, with Meb executing his technique throughout the race and especially in those last few miles. In a very close race, he was able to hold them off.
